content: AI is now capable of building, testing, debugging, and shipping entire applications from scratch, effectively replacing developers rather than just assisting them.
GPT-5.3 Codex was used to debug its own training process, indicating that AI is now improving AI, leading to an accelerating feedback loop.
Dario Amodei, CEO of Anthropic, predicts that 50% of entry-level white-collar jobs will be eliminated within one to five years.
Many business owners who formed their opinion on AI in 2023 based on early versions of ChatGPT have not updated their understanding, leading to a dangerous illusion of preparedness.
Dismissing current AI capabilities based on 2023 versions is like test driving a golf cart in 2023 and deciding you don't need to worry about Teslas in 2026.
The current iteration of AI is fundamentally different from its 2023 counterpart, capable of performing entire jobs rather than just answering questions.
Relying on ChatGPT for emails is an underutilization of AI, akin to using a rocket ship as a paperweight.
The belief that one's industry is immune to AI disruption is false, as all knowledge work fields (legal, finance, marketing, development, design, content) are being simultaneously impacted.
Delaying AI adoption until it becomes a necessity is dangerous, as competitors who started earlier will achieve 10x efficiency with half the headcount.
Adapting to AI only when necessary is like trying to adapt to a tidal wave while it's hitting you, rather than seeing it coming and moving to higher ground.
Businesses should transform employees into managers of AI systems, directing AI to perform tasks rather than performing them manually.
To implement AI-native workflows, identify the most repetitive, time-intensive workflow, build an AI system to handle 80% of it, and use the freed-up time for higher-value work.
AI cannot replace an audience, relationships, or trust, making these human elements critical for thriving in an AI-saturated world.
When AI makes content creation trivially easy, attention and trust become the primary bottlenecks, not production.
To build distribution, choose one platform and post daily for 90 days, sharing insights about AI in your industry to become an authority.
Taste is defined as the ability to curate, direct, and judge quality, stemming from experience, deep market knowledge, and understanding human resonance.
Service businesses are highly vulnerable to AI disruption because AI can often perform the same tasks, leading to dramatic margin compression.
AI is an incredible producer but a mediocre editor.
Businesses should productize their expertise by using AI to build scalable products that solve the same problems their services address, rather than relying solely on custom projects.
A human with great taste and AI tools will outperform a human with no taste and the same AI tools.
To develop taste: consume great work in your field, study what is effective, and form strong opinions about quality to better direct AI production.
To productize services, identify the most common client deliverable, build a v1 product using AI tools within a month, and test it with existing clients.
At Creme Digital, restructuring around AI-native workflows has more than doubled output per person in six months with a leaner team and higher quality.
The biggest opportunity of our lifetime, within the next 12 to 24 months, is for individuals who learn to build with AI.
People who document the shift to AI and help others navigate it will build the most valuable audiences and businesses of the next decade.
Most businesses will fail to act on the AI shift, continuing with outdated playbooks, leading to shrinking margins and faster competitors.
The playbook for navigating the AI shift involves becoming an orchestrator, owning distribution, building products, moving fast, and developing taste.
The window to position oneself on the right side of the intelligence explosion and accelerating AI feedback loop is open now but will not be open forever.
